results.title: The Godfather. Part III (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola and Zoetrope Studios
results.brief_description: In this special extended video version, re-edited by director Francis Ford Coppola to include additional footage never seen in cinemas, one of the greatest sagas in movie history concludes. Al Pacino reprises his role as the powerful family patriarch, Michael Corleone. Now in his sixties, Michael is dominated by two passions: freeing his family from their connections with the Mafia and finding a suitable successor. That successor could be his hot-headed, violence-prone nephew, Vincent, played by Andy Garcia, but he may also be the spark that turns Michael’s hopes of business legitimacy into an inferno of mob violence. Stars Diane Keaton as Michael’s long-suffering wife and Sofia Coppola as his wilful daughter, Mary, who is involved in a fiery affair with Vincent. Eli Wallach is one of the old dons of the Corleone family and Joe Mantegna is Michael’s arch-enemy Joey Zasa. This third film in the epic Corleone trilogy matches it’s predecessors in narrative intensity, socio- political analysis, physical beauty and depth of feeling for its characters. Original music by Carmine Coppola.

results.title: The Godfather. Part II (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola, Coppola Company and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description:
In this sequel to “The Godfather”, set in 1940s-50s, Michael Corleone has taken over his father’s mantle as head of the powerful Mafia family. Director Coppola tells two stories - the roots and rise of a young Don Vito, played by Robert De Niro, and the ascension of Michael Corleone (Al Pacino) as the new Don. Throughout the film, flashback sequences shot in a neorealist style, parallel the two lives of father and son. A complex, epic vision of the corruption of American society, the film is widely considered to be as good as, if not better than the original. It won several Academy Awards including Best Picture, Director, Supporting Actor (DeNiro), Screenplay, Score and Art direction/set decoration and was followed by “The Godfather. Part III” sixteen years later.
Cast also includes: Robert Duvall, Dianne Keaton, John Cazale, Talia Shire, Lee Strasberg, Michel V. Gazzo, Troy Donahue, and Danny Aiello. Original music by Carmine Coppola.

results.title: Gosford Park
results.creator_credit: Robert Altman, Bob Balaban, David Levy, Capitol Films, Film Council, Sandcastle 5 Productions and Zestwick Limited
results.brief_description: November 1932 - Gosford Park is the magnificent Estate of the unhappily married Sir William Cordle and Lady Sylvia. Immersed in an upper-class world of frippery, fine manners and nasty natures, various friends and associates gather for a weekend shooting party; when murder occurs, suspicious ulterior motives are revealed. But this narrative, largely related from the perspective of the servants, is less of a mystery than it is a comedy centering on the politics and mores of aristocratic society, the ‘upstairs’ shenanigans of which are mirrored by the equally fascinating world of footmen, butlers, valets, maids and cooks, who vehemently adhere to the below stairs strictures. With labyrinthine systems of etiquette and appropriate behaviours, these ‘downstairs’ caretakers are bland observers of their employers’ lives, who thrive on gossip and rumour, feeding off lascivious details and intricacies, whilst observing the treachery and mixed fortunes of their masters’ lives. Presenting over a score of well-defined players, it is a testament to Altman’s skill that none are mere ciphers, but rather sustain complex characterisations, creating a fascinating tableau of class politics, societal mores, perfidious interpersonal relationships and a cohesive panorama of human behaviour. Stellar cast includes: Eileen Atkins, Bob Balaban, Alan Bates, Charles Dance, Stephen Fry, Michael Gambon, Richard E. Grant, Tom Hollander, Derek Jacobi, Kelly Macdonald, Helen Mirren, Jeremy Northam, Clive Owen, Ryan Phillippe, Maggie Smith, Kristin Scott Thomas, Emily Watson and James Wilby.

results.title: A Beautiful mind [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Ron Howard, Brian Grazer, Imagine Entertainment (US) and NBCUniversal
results.brief_description: Ron Howard won accolades (including several Academy Awards) for “A Beautiful mind” which navigates the story of real life Nobel Prize winning mathematician, John Nash. A prodigious if arrogant mastermind, the socially gauche Nash starts at Princeton in 1947 and, after discovering his revolutionary game theory, is soon working as a lecturer at MIT. After being commandeered by the CIA as a code-breaker, Nash works in covert operations of a mysterious nature. After marrying, and worrying that his clandestine assignments are too dangerous to continue with, Nash is hospitalised and diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia. The film details Nash’s life over the next fifty years as he struggles with his mental illness and the weight of his intellect. The screenplay (adapted from the biography by Sylvia Nasar) takes great pains to emphasise that it is the support and love of his wife Alicia that aids this tortuous journey. Howard (Apollo 13, Parenthood, Cocoon) tackles an array of topics - psychological sickness, creativity, insanity, paranoia - but still manages to convey hope for his protagonist, partially (and controversially) by omitting any aspects of Nash’s life that does not fit the Hollywood mould of tortured genius. The adherence to predictable devices (soaring score, turgid dialogue, odes to the triumph of the human spirit) and a refusal to accommodate the more salacious (true) aspects of Nash’s life undermine an otherwise effective film.

results.title: Cats & dogs = Cats and dogs [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Guterman, Andrew Lazar, Chris DeFaria, Craig Perry, Warren Zide and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: A young beagle finds himself a player in a canines versus felines war when he is introduced to the Brody family. Now named Lou, he is quickly acquainted with Butch, Chief Agency Dog, who introduces him to fellow agents Peek and Sam, as well as tracing the origins of mission he is now an integral part of - Action Plan Delta. Action Plan Delta comprises of replacing the previous catnapped pet, Buddy, and guarding the Brody home from cat invasion. The cats are intent on entering the household to gain access to a serum Mr Brody has been perfecting - a serum which prevents dog allergies. In the wrong hands (paws), the serum could be reversed and create widespread dog allergies, thus allowing cats to become man’s best friend. Leader of the cat movement is a white feline with the undignified name of Mr Tinkles. When the cats infiltrate the Brody home the dogs cast a vote as to whether they should save family or formula. Featuring impressive special effects, “Cats & dogs” presents an interesting take on the spy/action genre (Mission Impossible in particular), with all that you’d expect to see in such a film: secret agents, Russian spies, inventive weapons and perverse interrogation techniques. It’s also concerned about the love between man and pet - with dogs in particular. Voices provided by Tobey Maguire (Lou), Alec Baldwin (Butch), Sean Hayes (Mr Tinkle), Susan Sarandon (Ivy), Michael Clarke Duncan (Sam) Joe Pantoliano (Peek) and Charlton Heston (the Mastiff). Cast also includes Elizabeth Perkins and Miriam Margolyes. Creature effects by Jim Henson’s Creature Shop.

results.title: Tigerland [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Joel Schumacher, Arnon Milchan, Beau Flynn, Steven Haft, Haft Entertainment, Kirch Media, New Regency Pictures and Regency Enterprises
results.brief_description: Tigerland is the name of a military base in the United States used for the training of recruits before they are to be sent to fight in the war in Vietnam. The film follows the recruits as they are increasingly pushed to the edge of their physical and mental capabilities by a dehumanising military regime convinced that only by brutalising the men will they be able to sufficiently face the terrors of the war ahead. Starring Colin Farrell as Roland Bozz, a young man whose independent spirit and questioning mind puts him immediately at odds with authority, “Tigerland” is a punishing but compelling view of army life. The actual war is in the background. It is as a study of masculinity, repressed sexuality and violence that the film is most effective. Usually known for bloated big-budget action films, director Schumacher has instead, in “Tigerland”, utilised hand-held camerawork, minimal special effects and a concentration on the performances of the actors to achieve his effects. As a late addition to the genre of Vietnam war film, “Tigerland” lacks the immediacy and hallucinatory contradictions of films such as “Apocalypse Now” or “The Deerhunter”: in many ways, for all its kinetic editing and camerawork, it is a traditional genre film. Nevertheless, the performances and the energetic direction ensures that it is both exciting and confronting.

results.title: Singin' in the rain [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Gene Kelly, Stanley Donen, Arthur Freed and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: The seemingly eternal freshness of “Singin’ in the rain” may be the result of an unusual degree of improvisation involved in its making. More than most musicals this was a team effort - a coming together of talents striving to overcome the limitations that they saw in the material and given space in which to move. In the process they not only produced one of the finest of movie musicals but also one of the best Hollywood-on-Hollywood movies - an intelligent and affectionate satire on the coming of synchronised sound. It is also a high point of what Richard Dyer calls the Utopian musical of the fifties which erased the distinction between the narrative and the musical numbers, the ultimate management of the contradiction between realism and fantasy inherent in the genre. Features catchy tunes, lively choreography with the athletic grace and Irish charm of Gene Kelly, engaging performances and hilarious jokes. Gene Kelly was co-director, choreographer and actor in this spectacular musical and in 1989 it was one of the first twenty-five films selected by the US Library of Congress for its National Film Registry of significant films.

results.title: The Glenrowan affair
results.creator_credit: Rupert Kathner and Australian Motion Pictures
results.brief_description: This film, based on the Ned Kelly legend, was filmed in and around Benalla by a specialist in low budget quickies with a local football hero, Bob Chitty as Ned. Told from the perspective of an ageing Dan Kelly in present day Benalla, the narrative is presented as a factual retelling of the exploits of the Kelly gang despite its obvious embellishment of the Kelly myth. The shortcomings of the script and its clumsy realisation were derided by the Benalla audience at its premiere and noted by press reviewers upon its brief Sydney release. Narrated by Charles Tingwell. Cast includes: Bob Chitty, Albie Henderson, Ben Crowe, Bill Wright, John Fernside, Chas. Tasman, Charles Webb, Edward Smith, Frank Ransom, Stan Tolhurst. Photography, Harry Malcolm ; editor, Alex Ezard ; sound, Berry Hallett.

results.title: The Princess bride [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Andrew Scheinman, Rob Reiner and ACT III Communications
results.brief_description: A young boy (Fred Savage), bedridden with the flu, is less than thrilled when his grandfather (Peter Falk) arrives to read aloud the book “The Princess bride”. The story, set in the fairyland kingdom of Florin, recounts the adventures of Buttercup (Robin Wright), the most beautiful woman in the world, and Westley (Cary Elwes), the man she loves. The grandfather promises fencing, chases, escapes, love and miracles. His grandson soon discovers that his adventure story delivers much more. Appearances by Billy Crystal, Carol Kane, Mel Smith and more. Music by Mark Knopfler. Based upon the story by William Goldman.

results.title: Catch 22 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Mike Nichols, John Calley, Martin Ransohoff, Filmways and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Mike Nichols directed this cinematic adaptation by Buck Henry of Joseph Heller’s scathing, iconic novel, “Catch 22.” Fresh from the success of the anti-establishment hit “The Graduate,” the pair attempted to present an anti-war treatise, epitomised in Heller’s prose. A tale of a small group of flyers in the Mediterranean in 1944, the story centres on Captain Yossarian, a pilot who is manic in his desire to fly no more missions and haunted by the death of a gunner. Yossarian’s plea that he is mad falls on deaf ears - if a pilot knows that flying is a death mission, he is clearly not mad. There are winners, losers, opportunists, and survivors; separately and together they are nervous, frightened, often profane and sometimes pathetic and almost all are a little crazy. Despite slavish adherence to the novel’s plot, Nichols never quite manages to capture the book’s anarchic flavour and thorny, intelligent wit. Nevertheless the film still serves as a timely reminder of the lunacy of combat and Heller’s titular clause retains a stinging indictment on the sanctioned idiocy of war. An all star cast includes Alan Arkin, Art Garfunkel, Anthony Perkins, Martin Sheen, Jon Voight, Orson Welles and Bob Newhart.
